loans.name: Altangerel

texts.en:
Altangerel N. is 42 years old and lives with his wife and two children in their own ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent, in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. His wife works in a cafe while his two children, 14 and 8, both attend a local secondary school. Altangerel operates a taxi service in his local community. He has been driving a vehicle for 20 years and since 2005, he started his taxi service. 

Over the many years of operation, he has provided a fast, good and reliable service to his customers. For the future, he plans to purchase one more car. Altangerel is a very honest and hardworking man. He says "I want to do some construction on my house where my family live".  He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to renovate his house.

loans.use: To renovate his house

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en:
Batjargal L. is 32 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and her family live together in a ger, a traditional housing tent. His wife works as a bookkeeper in a company while his two oldest children both attend a local elementary school. 

Batjargal operates a food retailing business out of a small shop. He recently started his business in 2010 and has built a stable operation. He is a modest and helpful man and says, "I want to enlarge my grocery store and to start operating a cafe next to my store." 

He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan both to increase the working capital for his store and to open new cafe for his future business.

loans.use: To open a new cafe

loans.name: Jargaltsetseg

texts.en:
Jargaltsetseg T. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and four children in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia.  She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her all four children, aged 16, 15, 10 and 8, study at the local school while her husband is currently unemployed. 

Jargaltsetseg operates a meat trading business in her town. She has been engaged this business since 2003 after moving from countryside and has built a stable operation. During the summer months, her husband operates a construction business in his town to supplement his family's income. She hopes to expand her business. 

Jargaltsetseg is requesting 1,000,000MNT loan in order to grow her working capital for her meat market business.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of meat

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg S. is a 54 years old married woman with two adult-aged children in Hovd province of western Mongolia. She and her family all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her oldest son works in the executive branch of the judicial system while her  youngest daughter currently attends university. Her husband is retired and helps Oyunchimeg's business. 

She operates a sewing business in her town. Oyunchimeg used to work as a seamstress for a sewing company. She has been engaged in this business for 15 years and has gained much experience. For the future, Oyunchimeg hopes to grow and increase her  business. She says, "I have been working as a seamstress for my entire life and today I am old aged but still operating this business. All I want is to help my son's wedding and continue to provide my daughter's tuition fees." 

Oyunchimeg is requesting a 1,050,000 MNT loan to purchase fabrics and silk materials at wholesale price from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and silk materials

loans.name: Baigalmaa

texts.en:
Baigalmaa T. is 34 years old and lives with her husband and one daughter in the Umnugobi province of Mongolia. She lives together with her family in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her daughter, 8, attends a local elementary school. Her husband works in a construction field. 

Baigalmaa manages a traditional Mongolian shoe-making business in her town. She makes a variety of Mongolian and Buridian shoes that that Mongolian wore in ancient times. She started her business in her home in 2002. She used to work as a seamstress for a company between 1996 and 1999 and as a master in a Bishrelt company between 1999 and 2000. 

She is planning to make warm boots for the mining workers. Her products are 80% handmade. She used her previous loan to purchase land with a fence where her workplace is located now. She is a very talkative and kind woman and says, "Person can not undervalue one's job, but job can undervalue person."  

She is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan to purchase fabrics and materials used in making her traditional shoes.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Galbadrah

texts.en:
Galbadrah L. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Hovd province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Both of his children attend attend a local kindergarten while his wife is currently unemployed. 

Galbadrah operates an iron/metalwork business by producing a variety of stoves and welding work. He has been engaged this business for past 12 years and has built a stable operation. He is a very hardworking man and is requesting a 2,100,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to purchase a large amount of steel plates at a wholesale price for making stoves.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of steel plates

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en:
Nergui B. is 57 years old and lives with her husband and family in the Tuv province in central Mongolian in their own ger, a traditional housing tent. Her husband is retired and receives a monthly pension of 81,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT). Her grandson currently attends a local secondary school. 

She operates a milk and milk products business in her town. She owns several cows that are all dairy cattle. She has been raising livestock since 2007 and has gained much experience. After years of successful operation, she has created a wide range of customers. Her earnings have enabled her to buy 10 cows for her daughter, who also operates a farming business. 

For the future, she plans to purchase more five milk breeding cows in order to expand her farming business. 

Nergui is a modest and hardworking woman and hopes to grow her farming by creating a big farm in her province. Nergui is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of grass and fodder for winter preparation.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of grass and fodder

loans.name: Tumurchudur

texts.en: Tumurchudur L. lives with her husband in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. She lives with her husband in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home. Her husband is a decorator and operates a construction business in his town during the summer months. In the winter, he helps his wife with her business. Tumurchudur operates a small cafe in a rented pavilion in her town. She started this business in 2006 and has built a stable operation. After years of successful operation, she managed to expand her business by purchasing a new ice cream machine. Her cafe specializes in making a variety of traditional Mongolian meals and is a popular dining establishment in her community. For the future, she is planning to own a pavilion that she currently rents. Her earnings have enabled her to purchase her own land with a fence. She is preparing to build a new house in her yard. She is very intelligent, modest, and hardworking. She says, "I used to run a dairy products trading business. In the future, I want to open my own dairy production factory based on my knowledge and skill." She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase food supplies.

loans.use: To purchase food supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: He wants to buy fresh fruits

loans.name: Tserenhuu

texts.en:
Tserenhuu D. lives with her husband and two daughters in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her oldest two daughters, 10 and 8, both attend a local school. Her husband is a veterinarian. 

Tserenhuu has been working as a hairdresser since 2004 after graduating from vocational hairdressing training. She currently works in a Zaluus salon. For the future, Tserenhuu hopes to have her own workplace. She works very hard and is a clever woman. She is requesting a 1,000,000 Mongolian Tugriks loan to purchase necessary tools and materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase necessary tools and materials

loans.name: Burulush

texts.en:
Burulush K. is a 53-year-old farmer who lives in the northern part of Kyrgyzstan. She has two children who live with her and help in the household. She graduated from Trade College and worked as an accountant. She is known as a purposeful, positive and sociable person. Burulush’s husband is engaged in farming.

Unfortunately, after the breakdown of the Soviet Union, Burulush lost her job. That is why in 1995, Burulush began to engage in stock-breeding using the 20,000 Kyrgyzstan soms (KGS) that she had put aside for a rainy day. At that time, she had only two calves. Gaining experience in cattle breeding, Burulush broadened her business and today owns 24 sheep, one milk cow, one calf and one horse. She also began to cultivate a plot of land with potatoes, kidney beans and perennial herbs.  

Burulush is a really hard-working woman. Her striving to provide her children with a better life motivated her to apply for a loan of 60,000 KGS for cattle breeding. She used her loan as intended and repaid it without any delays. 

Now, Burulush has decided to apply for a second loan of 60,000 KGS. She will use it to buy more milk cows. With the revenues, Burulush plans to build a barn for her cattle.

Kiva's field partner Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas. This leads to increased employment and meets the interests of both clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Damira

texts.en:
Damira O. lives in Orto-Saz village, which is situated in the high-mountain Naryn region. She is 50, married and has three children. One of them is of school-age and the others are grown-up. Damira works as a mailer and enjoys meeting many people and informing her village about the latest developments in the country. Her colleagues characterize her as a very sociable and responsible person. In order to find an additional means of subsistence for her family, Damira started her own business in cattle breeding. Using initial capital of 25,000 KGS to purchase livestock, she worked hard and achieved success. Today, Damira’s farm has three cows, one horse and 20 sheep. All these activities allowed Damira to give a good dowry to her daughter. Now Damira decided to apply for a loan of 35,000 KGS to purchase three calves. With the revenues from the loan, she plans to renovate a barn for her cattle. Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Haneen

texts.en:
Haneen Q. is a young woman from BetJala in Bethlehem district, Haneen is one of two daughters and two brothers for a handicapped father who can't work anymore. Her dad used to work in his supermarket but since he became handicapped, he stopped, and now her younger brothers take care of the supermarket.

Haneen started working at their house, she turned one of the rooms to a small beauty salon where she receives neighbors and friends, her house is near Al-Quds open university which secures a good numbers of customers.

Haneen helps her family covering life expenses and is trying to save money in order to have her own place one day.

loans.use: Purchase beauty products

loans.name: Muneer

texts.en:
Muneer is a young father from Bethlehem district, he used to work in Israel, he stopped working there as he is now banned from crossing to there. 
He rented a small shop in his area and started a grocery store, the store is the only source of income he and the family have. 

Muneer came to FATEN and took a $3,000 loan to buy the needed goods for the store. Muneer who appears in the picture is married and has two sons.

loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase mobiles

loans.name: Iman

texts.en:
Iman L. is a mother of two daughters, Iman was widowed and had to depend on her self to take care of her small family. Luckily, Iman started a small tailoring workshop in her house, which has become the household's only source of income since her husband passed away.

Iman took a couple of loans from FATEN to improve her workshop and now is taking a $500 loan to purchase a new tailoring machine. Iman's daughters work with their mother in the workshop where Iman appears in the picture above.

loans.use: Purchase a tailoring machine

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Riham

texts.en:
Riham is a mother of three sons and two daughters, her husband is an electricity technician, he installs electricity networks for houses. One of Riham's sons works as a taxi driver in the city where they live. Riham has received three loans and this is the fourth one that her son needed to perform maintenance and pay for car licensing expenses.

Riham has been a very good customer who repays in time, and her son is a well-respected young man who wants to help his father raising his brothers and sisters and share in house expenses needs.

Riham's son Younis appears in the picture next to the car as Riham doesn't think it's appropriate that her picture is published online, especially she is not the one driving the car.

loans.use: Car Maintenance

loans.name: Siham

texts.en:
Siham is a housewife and mother of two sons and three daughters, she started a small poultry farm in the backyard of her house seven months ago. Siham raises chicks and sells them to shops when they become mature chickens. 

Siham is responsible for the whole family as all her kids are very young and not able to work yet, therefore she came to FATEN and took a $800 loan to purchase a bigger number of chicks and prepare them for sale to shops.

Siham sells also to her neighbors as there's no chicken shop in the area which ensures a stable income for the family.
Siham appears in the picture in her small farm.

loans.use: Increase the number of chicks

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a farmer from the town of Kitale in western Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for four years. He is currently into small scale egg production, selling locally. His biggest challenge is marketing since most buyers prefer well established farmers only. He also runs a kiosk which supplements his income. John is 24 years old and single.

John recently repaid his previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 30,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) and has requested this loan of 45,000 KES to expand his poultry project. He says that he wants to further his studies on agricultural production, and the proceeds from this loan will go a long ways to support him. He also hopes that, in the future, he will be able to supply his eggs to all the secondary schools in his district. He appreciates the flexibility in the repayment system of Juhudi.

loans.use: To expand his poultry project

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last ten years. Her mixed farm produces maize, beans and vegetables which she sells locally. She also buys and sells vegetables at a local market. Grace is 33 years old and single.

Grace has requested this loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to expand her poultry business. She says that the extra income from this project will increase her savings and she will hopefully be able to purchase a piece of land in the future. She also hopes to own a sizable poultry farm and be the major supplier of eggs within her location. She is grateful to Juhudi for empowering her economically without discriminating against her despite the fact that she is disabled.

loans.use: To expand her poultry project

loans.name: Muna

texts.en:
Muna is a young woman who has two sons and five daughters, her husband is a Palestinian National Authority employee. One of her sons works in the grocery store the family owns, where they sell food supplies such as milk, coffee, sugar, salt, oil, wheat, etc.

Muna came to FATEN and received $800 to purchase a larger amounts of food supplies, since her stocks were mostly consumed during the month of Ramadan. Her store is supplying the area with a variety of supplies that are not available in most small supermarkets.

Muna's son who works in the store appears in the picture here as Muna is not comfortable having her picture online.

loans.use: Purchase food supplies

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas, 36 years old, is a married father of two children, ages 8 and 14, both of whom attend school. Thomas has been farming for the last 15 years in Kisii town, western Kenya, and employs two farmhands. His mixed farm produces maize, nappier grass and milk which he sells locally. He is also a carpenter.

Thomas has requested this loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. He faces the challenge of lack of finances to expand his businesses and irregular cash flows from the sale of milk. Despite the challenges he hopes to open a carpentry workshop and acquire more dairy cows in the future. He says that the income from this loan will enable him to pay school fees for his children and develop more businesses that will increase the income of his family. 

Thomas is thanking Juhudi for the support and requests the interest rates be reduced.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Evans

texts.en:
Evans is a farmer from the town of Kisii in western Kenya, where he has been practicing mixed farming for 10 years. His mixed farm produces maize and milk, which he sells locally. He also earns income from his carpentry services for the local market. 

Evans is 32 years old and married with two children, ages 4 and 1. His eldest child attends school.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo in the amount of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the income from this loan will enable him to purchase another dairy cow that will increase his income and also expand his carpentry business. His primary challenges are price fluctuations and climatic changes, which affects the animal feeds. He plans to acquire another piece of land in the future to cultivate more maize and nappier grass and also expand his carpentry workshop.

He is thankful to Juhudi for the rural-based projects that have improved the living standards of the people.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Rawya

texts.en:
Rawya is a mother of two daughters and two sons: Yousef, Amro, Suhair and Hadeel, her sons and daughters age between 20-25 years old, Yousef works in a bank while Amro works in a restaurant. Rawya's husband is a National Palestinian Authority employee.

Rawya started her small project at home, she rented a shop to sell chickens for the neighborhood, Rawya received a $1,000 loan from FATEN to purchase a larger number of chicken and increase her profit. Rawya dreams of having a family business where her husband, sons and daughters work with her and help her grow the project bigger.

Rawya's son Yousef appear in the picture here as Rawya doesn't want to have her picture online.

loans.use: Purchase chicken

loans.name: Sebedeo

texts.en:
Seventy-two-year-old Sebedeo is a married father of six children who are all adults. He is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya, where he has been farming for 50 years and employs two farmhands. His main products are tea and milk, which he sells locally. He also earns income from his rental houses in the same area.

He recently repaid his previous loan of 35,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 40,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. The income from this loan will help him expand his farming and rental businesses. His primary challenges are unpredictable weather conditions, lack of labor and lack of enough finances to expand his business.

He hopes that in five years time, he will have expanded his dairy farming and rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is a farmer from the town of Kisii in western Kenya. He has been farming for 10 years and employs two farmhands. His mixed farm produces maize, beans, bananas and milk, which he sells locally. He also sells seeds and seedlings to the local market.

Simon has requested this loan of 50,000 Kenyan Shillings to purchase a dairy cow. He says that the income from this loan will help him to pay school fees for his children and he will also be able to provide enough milk for domestic consumption. He faces the challenge of a lack of labor and financing to expand his farming business.

Simon is 32 years old. He is married with two children, ages 6 and 5. Both children attend school.

He is thankful to Juhudi for supporting the peasant farmers and helping them financially. He requests, however, that Juhudi reduce the interest rates to enable farmers to benefit more.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Rawya

texts.en:
Rawya J. is a 28 years housewife and mother of four children, Lina, Nour, Jihad and Yaser, the children are 12, 10, 7 and 6 years old respectively. Rawya's husband is a Palestinian National Authority Employee, Rawya wanted to have the store so she helps her husband cover life expenses.

Rawya sells house accessories and tools such as vases, frames, paintings, dishes, spoons, cups, etc.
Rawya came to FATEN to take a $600 to purchase goods she needs in the store, Rawya is very happy helping her husband and that she received a loan which will increase the returns.

Rawya's husband Muhamamd appears in the picture above as Rawya lives in Gaza which is a conservative region.

loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Johaida

texts.en: Johaida T. is a married woman who lives in Jesusito Village, Brgy. San Jose, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a tricycle transport business. Her husband Edison, who is 48 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who range from 10 to 25 years old. Johaida joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Johaida has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her seventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to purchase one motorcycle with a sidecar so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Johaida T. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase a transport vehicle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Joelinda

texts.en: Joelinda T. is a 29-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating four business ventures: pig fattening, coco wine vending, tempura vending and banana vending businesses. She lives in Hda. Carmen, Brgy. Daan Banua, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. Joelinda has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1997 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Joelinda is now borrowing 13,000 PHP so that she can fund her business operations. This will be her seventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 12,000 PHP (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey towards economic freedom. Joelinda hopes to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional capital to fund businesses

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aynash

texts.en:
Aynash M. lives in the southern Kyrgyz city of Osh. She is 41, married and has three children. Two of them are students and the youngest son is a schoolboy. She graduated from Osh State University with the major in Kyrgyz philology (the study of literary texts and written records). Taking into account that salaries of teachers are very low and do not cover expenses of the families, Aynash decided to start her own business in shoe sales. She started with the sum of only 600 Kyrgyz soms (KGS) and bought several rubber boots for reselling. Aynash explored every avenue in her wish to support her children and achieved success – her two little shops became known by their wide assortments of shoes, where every client could find his favorite model.  

But in June 2010, when violent clashes caused by the deposed political regime broke out in the city of Osh, Aynash lost her business, which was fully destroyed. Her shops were robbed and looted. 

In spite of this severe test she went through, Aynash is ready to resume her lost business and continue to work. For this very reason, Aynash is applying for a loan of 135,000 KGS, which she needs to restart her activity. She plans to purchase shoes to resell at the local market. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase shoes for retail

loans.name: Ma. Leonora

texts.en:
Ma. Leonora D. is from the town of Banga. She is 39 years old. Ma. Leonora is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Leonora raises crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Ma. Leonora has been in her business for over 13 years.

Ma. Leonora joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ma. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase sacks of fertilizers and seeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Mary Joy

texts.en:
Mary Joy L. is from the town of Banga. She is 29 years old. Mary Joy is married and has a three-year-old child. To make a living, Mary Joy owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice to sell. Mary Joy has been engaged in her business for over four years.

Mary Joy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Joy has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Mary Joy is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Mary Joy from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan L. is from the town of Banga. She is 50 years old. Susan is married and has four children. Susan grows hogs for fattening and sale and tills a rice farm with her husband. She also runs a sari-sari (variety) store, where she sells a variety of different products. Susan works hard to provide for her family. It is also her dream for her kids to have bright futures.

Susan joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Susan is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase livestock feed, farm supplies and additional store supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed, farm supplies and additional store supplies

loans.name: Lani

texts.en:
Lani D. is from the town of Banga. She is 42 years old. Lani is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Lani raises crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice and corn. Lani has been farming for over 21 years.

Lani joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Lani is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use additional revenue to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn G. is from the town of Banga. She is 50 years old and married. She has four girls and two boys. To make a living, Jocelyn plants and harvests rice for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in farming for over 25 years.

Jocelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
This is 35-year-old Abibatu. She is married and has two children, aged 8 and 14 years. In 2005, Abibatu established her gara (dyed fabric) materials business. She began her business because she knew it from childhood. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about 1200000 Sierra Leone leones (Le) every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Abibatu requires a loan in order to add more stock and buy raw materials for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 250,000. In the future, Abibatu plans to establish a savings account and educate her children with part of her profit to support her husband. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to produce clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for her business.

loans.name: Marianna

texts.en:
Marianna owns a cafeteria. She is an entrepreneur from Beregovo, western Ukraine. Marianna’s business is located close to the local train station. There are no competitors, which is a big advantage of her small venture. Marianna has been in this business for 13 years. Presently, she has 35,000 Grivnyas invested in merchandise in her café. Her monthly profit amounts to 5,000 Grivnyas. 

Marianna is seeking a 10,000 Grivnya loan to purchase merchandise for her café. Her rich experience working in the sphere of public catering has helped her learn the tricks of the trade. Marianna realizes this sphere of business is very prospective. She is willing to work hard to succeed and make her business flourish even more in the future.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Sergio Nolberto

texts.es:
Sergio es mecánico de carros, trabaja desde las 09h00am todos los días. Vive en una zona periurbana llamada Perimetral. Su esposa es empleada domestica y tienen tres hijos. 

Por la falta de oportunidades y para poder mantener a su familia el comenzó trabajando en su casa reparando los carros de sus vecinos poco a poco fue conocido desde que atrapo un ladrón del vecindario.  Con ayuda de sus hijos repara, lubrica los carros. Tiene ya un pequeño taller en la parte delantera de su casa. El tiene muchas metas planificadas pero para iniciar necesita compran con el préstamo repuestos para venderlos y así obtener dinero para su familia. 

En el futuro quiere tener otro taller mecánico pero con una gama de repuestos a la venta de todos sus clientes. También poder terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Sergio is an auto mechanic who works every day starting at 9am. He lives in a periurban area called Perimetral. His wife works as a housekeeper and they have three children.

Due to a lack of opportunities and the need to support his family, he began working from home by repairing his neighbors’ vehicles. Little by little, he became well-known after capturing a burglar in the neighborhood. He repairs cars and performs oil changes with the help of his children. His small shop is located in the front part of his house. Sergio has many goals, but in order to get started, he will use this loan to buy spare parts to sell. This will allow him to generate income for his family.

In the future, he wants to open another repair shop with a variety of spare parts to sell to his customers. Sergio also wants to finish the construction of his house.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase spare parts

loans.name: Mujeres Con Visión (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El Banco comunal Mujeres con Visón, esta formado por un grupo de 11 señoras que trabajan en diferentes actividades para mejorar su situación económica y así sacar  adelante a sus familias. Viven en diferentes lugares de la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es  conocida por su belleza arquitectónica, sus bellos paramos, su cultura, su gastronomía y  por su gente que es calida y cordial

La Señora Carmen Margarita Y. vive en la ciudad de Cuenca por el sector de Quinta Chica, este es el segundo crédito que realiza en la banca comunal, ha llegado a tener una muy buena amistad con todas las socias que la conforman. Nuestra socia es muy joven tiene 25 años, es casada y tiene 4 hijos de 8, 7, 5 y 3 años de edad, sus tres primeros hijos  estudian en una escuela de la ciudad, su esposo trabaja en una fabrica realizando estucos (Cielos rasos), no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando.
Doña Carmen se dedica hace 3 años a la venta de productos Yanbal, L´bel etc, sus  ventas las realiza los días Lunes, Martes y Viernes, no tiene una horario fijo, los demás días vende pero muy poco ya que también les dedica tiempo a sus hijos que aun se encuentran pequeños. Su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra más cosméticos de la marca Yanbal como perfumes, cremas etc.
 
Su meta es  llegar a realizar su casa propia.

La Señora Mayra Alexandra S. vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, este es su tercer crédito que realiza  en la fundación y fue invitada por su mamá, los créditos le han beneficiado mucho en su negocio. Se dedica a la venta de cosméticos de la marca Avon,  actividad que la realiza hace un año. También trabaja como mesera en un restaurante lleva 8 meses en este trabajo y labora desde las 7 a.m. hasta las 3 p.m. 
Doña Mayra tiene  24 años, es casada y tiene una hija de 5 años de edad  que está  en un jardín de infantes de la ciudad. Su esposo trabaja como guardia de seguridad, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando.Su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de cosméticos de la marca Avon.
 
Su meta es  llegar a construir su casa propia.
texts.en:
The communal bank Mujeres con Visón (Women with Vision) is made up of 11 women who do different kinds of work to improve their economic situation and thus move their families ahead. They live in different places in the city of Cuenca. This city is known for its architectural beauty, its beautiful mountain landscape, its culture, its food and for the warmth and hospitality of its people. Mrs. Carmen Margarita Y. lives in the city of Cuenca by the Quinta Chica area. This is her second loan that she has taken with the communal bank. She has developed a good friendship with all the members of the bank. Our member is very young. She is 25, married, and has 4 children: 8, 7, 5 and 3. Her three oldest children are in a school in the city. Her husbands works in a factory making stucco ( ceilings). They don’t have their own home so that live in a rented one. Mrs Carmen has worked for the last 3 years selling Yanbal, L’bel products, etc. She sells on Mondays, Tuesday and Fridays. She doesn’t have a regular schedule. The others days she sells only a little since she also has to spend time with her children who are still young. She will use her loan to buy more Yanbal cosmetics such as perfumes, creams, etc. He goal is to have her own home. Mrs. Mayra Alexandra S. lives in the city of Cuenca. This is her third loan that she has taken with the foundation and she was invited by her mother. The loans have greatly benefited her in her business. She sells Avon cosmetics, work that she has done for the past year. She has also been a waitress in a restaurant for the last 8 months and she works from 7 am to 3 pm. Mrs. Mayra is 24, married and has a 5 year old daughter who is in the kindergarten of the city. Her husband is a security guard. They don’t have their own home so they live in a rented one. She will use the loan to buy Avon cosmetics. Her goal is to have her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Yanbal and Avon cosmetics, perfumes, creams and costume jewelry.

loans.name: Dionesia's Group

texts.en: Dionesia K. is from the village of Magsaysay, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Dionesia is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Millions. Dionesia is married and has an adult child. To make a living, Dionesia owns and operates a retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products such as canned goods, noodles, sugar, shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Dionesia has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 1,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Dionesia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dionesia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Dionesia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Um T., 46, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for being the most populated city in the country. She sells groceries for an income of $3.30 per day. Her husband is employed at a private company, earning an income of $5 per day.  

T. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en: Wilma E. is a married woman who lives in Portland, Kahumayan, Danao, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store business. Her husband Tomas E., who is 48 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn a living, and helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children, who are 15 and 22 years old and currently going to school. Wilma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Wilma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,400, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future, to help her husband with their daily needs, to improve her living conditions and to educate the children. In the photo is Wilma and her husband. Wilma E. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida M. is a married woman who lives in Bungtod, Manlayag, Danao City, Cebu. She earns a living through her pig fattening, chicken trading and basket weaving businesses. Her husband, Pacifico M. Jr. (44), helps his wife run her businesses. They have 5 children aged 6 to 20. 

Nida joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 2 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nida has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 3,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,400, thus raising the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 3rd cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for her children's education. Nida M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 



About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team."

loans.name: 04.01.18 Thieu Phu - Thieu Hoa Group

texts.en:
Hue H. T. (66) is a 30-year-old femaL. living in the town of Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  Hue is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 18 Thieu Phu - Thieu Hoa(04.01.18).


Hue is married and has one school-aged child.  To making a living, Hue operates a family member's business venture raising cattL. for saL..  Hue has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2010, Hue joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Hue is requesting a loan for the first time from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She is requesting a new loan of 4,248,000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  Hue plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  H. T. Ngo (65) is a 62-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


2.  L. T. Duyen (68) is a 24-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Hue H. T. (66) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  Hue là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 18 Thieu Phu - Thieu Hoa(04.01.18).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Hue thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Hue kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2010, Hue đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Hue đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4.248.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 12th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  H. T. ngo (65) là 62 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  L. T. Duyen (68) là 24 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

To make a living, Edma owns & operates a business selling snacks & other delicacies like baked rice cake or bibingka in the local community. Edma has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Edma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Edma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Edma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Nelida

texts.en:
Nelida G. is a 51-year-old woman who has four children with her husband, Dante G., a fish vendor. Her two eldest children are already finished college and currently working professionally, the third eldest is a graduating student taking up criminology and her youngest is in his 1st year college. Every year, the education of Nelida's children incurs more financial expenses. Nelida's business had been very helpful to supplement these expenses and has enabled her children to continue their studies.

Nelida has been in the hog fattening business for more than 10 years. The hogs are raised for approximately four to six months until they are ready for sale. After four months of raising or fattening, the pigs will be sold either alive or slaughtered for their meat per kilo.

Nelida's membership in ASHI and the support of her loving husband and children enabled her to put this together and see it grow. Despite financial struggles, Nelida proved her trustworthiness and well-defined values by showing good performance in terms of her repayments, attendance and business.

Recently, Nelida, her husband and her children decided to apply for a loan with ASHI to enhance her business further to earn a larger profit. The whole family agreed on the idea of buying more pigs to raise and have bigger profit. Aside from intending Nelida's loan for her primary business, they also plan to support and enhance their fish selling business for an alternative income source.

Through the profit of Nelida's hog fattening business, she aspires to invest in her home; the profit from her fish selling business will be intended for her weekly payments to ASHI, her family's daily needs, and children's education.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to raise and to support  secondary business of fish selling.

loans.name: Janet's Group

texts.en:
Janet B. is from the village of Flores. She is 43 years old. Janet is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Janet B..

Janet is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Janet owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Janet is just starting this business.

In 2010, Janet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janet is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Janet from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Belsie

texts.en:
Belsie F. is a hardworking married woman who offers transport services to earn a living. Belsie and her husband use a tricycle to offer short distance transport service for goods and people. A tricycle is a motorcycle with a sidecar attached, used as a public vehicle. A tricycle is much more expensive than tri-bike; however, owners have a better income. 

She has been in this business for more than ten years. Belsie appreciates that the Kiva partner, ASHI, has helped her improve her business which has raised her family's living standards. She has requested a loan of 49,000 PHP to buy another tricycle. Some of the money will support the maintenance of it. She hopes to buy more tricycles in the future for better income. She sees herself venturing into a jeepney (small bus) business in the next ten years.

Having this opportunity of a loan from KIVA through ASHI will provide a chance to achieve her ambitions in life. She wants to renovate their home, enjoy a good life and have the financial means to support her family and fund the college education of her grandchildren.

She also dreams of having a pump boat to be managed by her eldest child, Jovan, who already has his own family. She hasn’t stop dreaming for her children to have their own businesses like she does. Belsie wants to thank ASHI and Kiva lenders who are sponsoring this loan. This process is one of the greatest opportunities for her to start reaching for her goals.

loans.use: To buy another tricycle and some of the money will support the maintenance of it.

loans.name: Phen

texts.en: Phen P., 33, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. P. is a housewife while her husband is a cameraman, earning an income of about $10 per day.  P. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a new camera and other photography business needs to improve her husband's business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a new camera and other photography business needs

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Mr. Oeun S. (pictured here), 44, and his wife, Mrs. Born Man, 40, live in a small village on National Road Two about 20 kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1990 and have three daughters. Two of them are garment factory workers and another one is in school.  

Oeun is a motor taxi driver. He also assists his wife’s  fish selling business. He is applying for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for his daughters to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for his daughters to drive to work.

loans.name: La

texts.en:
Mrs. La C., (was in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Chork Kao, live in a small village off of National Road number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1982 and have four children. One of them is a chef, another one is a security guard, and the others are in school. 

Mrs. La C. has been selling vegetables, meat and groceries for more than 10 years. Her husband is a farmer; he also raises cows at home. La had a Kiva loan previously to purchase a motorcycle for commuting. 

She now wants to purchase a motorbike for her children to get to school. So, she is requesting her second loan of $300 to make this purchase.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to school.

loans.name: Sophon

texts.en:
Mr. Sophon R. (shown in the photo), is 26 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Sophat Korng, 28, have been married for 3 years. They are living in a small village along National Road number five approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sophon is a construction worker. His wife is a garment factory worker. Besides these jobs, the couple are rice farmers as well. 

Sophon is asking for his first loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase a motorized hand tiller to use on his rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase a motorized hand tiller to use on his rice farm.

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarorn S. (pictured here), is a widow with four sons and two daughters. Four of them are married and live outside the family home. One son attends university and another daughter is also a widow living with her. They are living on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Mrs. Sarorn S. is a silk weaver and a tailor. She is old, but still strong and works hard. She hopes to support her son's further education, so she is asking for a loan of $1,200 to pay school fees for her son who is attending university. She will use a part of her loan to buy silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her son who is attending university and buy silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Em S., 47, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. S. is a housewife while her husband is an electronics repairman, earning an income of USD 2.5 per day.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S. appears in the photograph with her son.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work

loans.name: Prak

texts.en:
Prak N., 56, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantations. N. sells traditional cakes for an income of USD 4 per day.

Prak N.’s husband is a motor-taxi driver, also earning an income of USD 4 per day. N. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to improve his business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

This is Prak N.’s second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for her husband to improve his business

loans.name: Nonieta

texts.en:
Nonieta is a 53-year-old married woman with three adult children. All of her children are degree holders: the eldest child is a nurse, the second eldest is a management accountant, and the youngest graduated with a major in accountancy.

As an active entrepreneur, Nonieta has been running a sari-sari store for almost eight years. ”Sari” is a native word for “variety”. This is a small store that is either attached to the owner’s house or in a small native cottage not far away. Such stores are convenient for people in the village who live far from the marketplace.

To assist in building her business, Nonieta would like to receive a loan of 30,000 PHP to increase the inventory of goods sold in her sari-sari store. She is planning to purchase additional products such as rice, sugar, eggs, cooking oil and other stock for her store. She believes that offering a wide assortment of goods to customers will increase traffic to her store and maintain customer loyalty in her village.

A loyal member since 2002 of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Nonieta has been a model member demonstrating regular attendance at weekly center meetings and steady repayments on previous loans. Her longterm goals are to offer a better future for her family and to sustain the profitability of her store.

Through hard work and determination, Nonieta is focused on improving her quality of life with the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Nodir

texts.ru: Ризоев Нодир проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 43 года. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Образование высшее, преподаватель. Работает по профессии. В свободное от работы время вместе с женой занимается торговлей на рынке "Зенсклад" и "Панчшанбебозор". Он в основном продает разную мелочь и одежду. Сейчас клиент построил магазин у себя дома и хочет его открыть. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. На полученную прибыль хочет оплатить учебу своего сына.
texts.en:
Nodir R. lives in Yavan. He is 43 years old, married, and has two children. He has a degree in teaching. He works in his trade. During free time from work, he and his wife trade in the Zensklad and Panchshanbebozor markets. He basically sells knickknacks and clothes. Now, the client has built a shop in his home and wishes to open it. He is taking out a loan to increase his sales. With his profits, he would like to pay for his son’s education.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Merlabel

texts.en: Merlabel C. is from the village of Consuelo, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 47 years old and is married with six school-aged children. Merlabel owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Merlabel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Merlabel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline A. is from the village of Santiago, Gingoog City. She is 36 years old and is married with two school-aged children.

Jacqueline is into motorcycle transport business, she owned a unit of motorela used to transport passengers in the place where her husband is the operator. Aside from owning a unit, she also has a sari sari store as another source of income . She has been engaged in her businesses for over two years and earns approximately 6,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jacqueline joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital.

Jacqueline is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Elena

Elena owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Elena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Elena is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. loans.name: Maryjane

texts.en:
Maryjane A. is from the village of Malibud, Gingoog City. She is 58 years old. Maryjane is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Maryjane owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Maryjane has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Maryjane joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maryjane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Maryjane is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Maryjane from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Floralie

texts.en: Floralie E. is a married woman who lives in Treplin, Barangay Binaobao, Bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living from a vegetable-vending business. Her husband, Lumelo E., who is 34 years old, is a businessman and also helps in his wife's business. They have four children who are from 6 to 14 years old and are currently going to school. Floralie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 7th loan, Floralie is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use as an additional capital to buy stock so that she can continue to save for the future to buy a delivery truck. Floralie is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josephine Mumbi

texts.en:
Josephine N. is a 43-year-old married mother of four children aged between 12 years and 21 years. She is married to John Soita, a quarry businessman. Josephine is a secondhand-clothes seller and has operated her business for one year.

Josephine was introduced to KADET by an existing client and is now accessing her first loan. She plans to buy more clothes stock and to build a stall to sell her clothes in. She has been selling most of her clothes to the residents of Takaungu in Kilifi.

In the future, Josephine hopes to see her stall expand and meet the expectations and needs of all her customers.

loans.use: To buy more clothes stock and to build a stall to sell her clothes in

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia O. is from the village of Bacnor West. She is 41 years old and is married with one school-aged child.

Delia owns and operates a business providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Delia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service.

Delia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en:
Douglas C. is a 42-year-old married father of three children. He is a dairy farmer in Tezo-Busulubu in Kilifi and has been operating his business for four years. He hopes to diversify into a carpentry business to supplement his income from his dairy cattle.

Douglas joined KADET recently and this marks his first borrowing. He plans to buy animal feeds for his cattle and also purchase some timber and begin his carpentry business. He mainly serves the residents of Tezo in Kilifi. He hopes to be a very successful entrepreneur.

loans.use: To buy feeds for his cattle and also some timber to begin his carpentry business

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa B. is from the village of Bacnor West. She is 43 years old and is married with one school-aged child.

Marissa operates a retailing business, selling a variety of different products in the local community with the use of her motorcycle. She sells meat, vegetables, fish and other basic commodities to her customers through house to house around their village. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Marissa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering.

Marissa is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her child’s tuition fees.


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Karisa

texts.en:
Karisa K. is a 30-year-old married father of two children aged eight years and four years. His wife, Peris Tabu, is a tailor.

Karisa is a carpenter in Kilifi and his business has been in operation for six years. He is borrowing his first loan from KADET and plans to buy trees in KIlifi to split and make timber. He operates his carpentry business in an area called Kwa Charo Wa Mae and his customers are the area locals.

Karisa hopes to become successful and meet all his family’s needs.

loans.use: To buy trees in Kilifi to split and make timber

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima F. is a 51-year-old married mother of seven children. She has a secondhand clothes business in Kilifi and mainly hawks her wares around Kituoni village in Kilifi. Other customers also come to buy the clothes at her home. She has been selling secondhand clothes for ten years and it has been a success.

Halima has been a good KADET client and is now borrowing her third loan. She plans to add more stock of clothes and build a stall to display her stock.

In the future, Halima hopes to see her business expand fully and be in a position to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes and build a stall to display her stock
