loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
Batbayar H. is a 34-year-old married man who lives with his wife and three children in Uvs province, Mongolia. They live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in a rented yard. His oldest two children, aged 12 and 8, both attend a local school while his youngest daughter, 2, is in kindergarten. His wife is currently unemployed.

Batbayar operates a transportation service business in his province. In winter he transports coal and in the summertime carries a variety of loads such as wood, glass, brick, etc., to sell at the local market at a profit. He owns a large transport truck with trailer.

Batbayar has been engaged in this business since 2002 and has found success as a truck driver. His truck can transport a load of up to ten tons, which allows him to make three to five trips per month. He earns between 300,000 and 400,000 MNT from each trip.

For the future, Batbayar hopes to purchase a new Japanese truck in order to transport between provinces. He says, "I work hard to buy a new plot of land with a fence for my family."

Batbayar needs more funds to repair his truck and is therefore requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase four new tires and a new engine for his truck.

loans.use: To purchase four new tires and a new engine for his truck

loans.name: Akbar

texts.ru: Чаборов Акбар проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 21 год. Холост. Мать учительница, преподает в средней школе. Брат на заработках в России. Сам Акбар имеет среднее образование. Занимается торговлей на рынке. У него продуктовый магазин. Он в основном продает конфеты и печенья. В этой области имеет  хороший опыт. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота т.к. на канун праздников спрос на его товар увеличивается. На будущее он хочет собрать деньги, чтобы устроить свою свадьбу.
texts.en:
Akbar J. lives in Yavan. He is 21 years old and single. His mother is a high school teacher. His brother works in Russia. Akbar has a high school education. He works trading in the market. He has a grocery shop. He basically sells candy and cookies. He has a good deal of experience in this area. He is taking out a loan to increase his sales since demand increases near the holidays. In the future, he wants to raise money to get married.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Florinda

texts.en:
Florinda is from San Jose, Antique. She is 55 years old. She is married and has three adult children. To make a good living, Florinda owns and operates a vegetable vending business at Trade Town of San Jose. Florinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns good profits for these activities. In 1999, Florinda aimed to join ASHI to secure access to financial services to help improve her living condition and to have the ability to engage in more business activities. Florinda has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASHI. Since she was able to repay her previous loan, she is now qualified to apply for another loan with a higher amount than the first one she had. Now, she plans to utilize this and future loans in the same business until it grows. She wishes that some day, she can put up her own stall, not rent in the public market, so that her income will increase and she will be able to give her customers convenient purchases in their village that is far away from the marketplace.

She hopes that, with the help of this KIVA field partner, she can reach her ambitions to step out from under the umbrella of poverty, develop her business, and provide for the needs of her grandchildren in school.

Florinda's aspiration for all of her children is for them to have a decent living, and this is the reason she wants her business to succeed. Her loan in ASHI is a very important factor that could lead her towards fulfillment. With her hard work, focus, and determination, Florinda is hopeful that her business ventures will continue to grow and improve the overall standard of living for her entire family.

loans.use: To use for selling vegetables.

loans.name: Byambaa

texts.en:
Byambaa C. is a 45 year old married woman with three children. She lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent, with her family in Huvsgul province of Mongolia. Her two oldest children attend university and her youngest daughter attends a local high school. Her husband is a driver of a horse cart and transports a load to supplement his family income.

Byambaa operates a dairy trading business in her town. She purchases a large amount of dairy products from herders at wholesale price and sells back in a local market at retail price. She has been engaged in this business for 5 years and has built a stable operation. Over the years of operation, she has managed to expand her business and increase her product line, which sells 10 types of dairy products today. For the future, she hopes to grow her business by adding more product types. She is a very modest and hardworking person. Her earnings have enabled her to pay her children's tuition fees. Byambaa is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more dairy supplies from herders in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy supplies.

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra lives in a city called Gujranwala in Pakistan with her husband and two sons in a 3 room brick house. She is a very talented lady, makes beautiful embroidery on clothes and then sells them in different shops of the market to earn income. Her husband has a business of selling electronic items in the market from where he not only sells electronic items, but also offers his electronics repair services to the customers. Due to his good command of his work he receives good orders for repairing electronics every month. Both of Azra’s sons are involved in her embroidery business. They have rented a shop in the nearby market from where they run their embroidery business.
   
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount he will buy electronic items, such as irons and sandwich makers, and also buy some of the latest electronics repair tools. Azra is confident that her husband has good work experience in his field and he will do well with his business by making this investment in it.
 
She is a new loan applicant. She hopes that it will be a good experience for her and she will continue her relationship with Asasah.

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.name: Bwizi Network Of People Living With Hiv, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
Four years is the time Florence N. has spent overseeing her bar business at Bwizi trading centre, Kyenjojo, after dropping her former agricultural enterprises. She started it with her savings after getting advice from successful friends in the same business. She sells soft drinks like sodas, and beer and local gin, which she does alongside farming. Once her business was on a firm footing, she has been able to make the best out of it.
 
In a month, this focused married mother of 8 children gets 100,000 Ugandan shillings as her monthly profit. With this money she has managed to cater for all her children’s education needs and general family welfare. She has come to grips with some inevitable business challenges; she has however not lost heart. The determination she carries with her means she is full of optimism that the future of her business will be B.. 

She belongs to Bwizi Network of people living with HIV group in KYENJOJO. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: To buy more stock of beers and sodas for the bar.

texts.en:
Ronald M., from the village of Brgy. Calaocan, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya, is 23 years old, married, and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Ronald owns and operates a general store selling a variety of products in the local community. Engaged in his business for over five years, he earns approximately 3500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Ronald joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting his first loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, Ronald plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Manueli

texts.en: Hard-working and determined N. Manueli, aged 34, has been operating a livestock business rearing and selling goats in Ikoba trading centre, Kyenjojo. A married father of three children, he purchases goats which he grazes, fattens and sells. His wife works alongside him selling produce.This brings in 400,000 Ugandan shillings a month that has helped him in taking on family responsibilities like paying the children’s school fees. He wants to restock his goats on the farm and needs this loan to help motive him, earn more sales revenue, and thus improve the family's income.

loans.use: purchase more goats for fattening

loans.name: Dorah

texts.en: Dorah M. is 25 years old, married, and the mother of one child. She runs a retail shop in Kibaoni, Kilifi, opposite Pwani University. Her business, which she has operated for three years, is doing well. Dorah has been a good KADET LTD client and is now taking out her third loan. With this money Dorah plans to buy wheat flour, five bags of sugar, maize flour and other assorted goods for her retail shop. She manages to make an income of Ksh. 30,000 a month. Her husband, Mureithi, is a businessman in Kilifi who also runs a retail shop to supplement the family income. Dorah hopes to improve her shop even further and open another outlet in the future.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, sugar, maize flour and other assorted goods for her retail shop

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en: Abdallah K. is a 32-year-old single businessman in Mombasa who has a grocery store in Mombasa's Kongowea market. His business is five years old and is doing well. This loan is Abdalla's first from KADET LTD, and with the money he plans to increase his stock of vegetables and tomatoes. He intends to save the profits from the sales and open another grocery in another location in Mombasa. Abdallah hopes to live a happy and successful life.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita A. is from the village of Agay-ayan, Gingoog City. She is 57 years old and widowed with four adult children. To make a living, Merlita runs a sari-sari (variety) shop selling both food and daily-use products. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Merlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Merlita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy essential materials for his bakery

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha M. is a 26-year-old married mother of one child. Aisha is a businesswoman who owns a motor vehicle and motorcycle spare parts shop in Mwembe tayari, Mombasa. She has been in this business for seven months and says it is doing well. She has plans to expand the business to Malindi town soon.

Aisha is borrowing her first loan from KADET LTD to finance her business and plans to use the money to purchase more stock of spare parts. Her husband is also a businessman in Mombasa and assists in the family income. Aisha hopes to be very successful in the business and be able to keep her family living standards as good as possible.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of spare parts

loans.name: Bukere Twimukye Group, Mubende

texts.en:
Hardworking and married, M. Amos has been operating a new garment sales business for 4 years from Kyaka Trading Centre, Mubende. This determined and innovative man has, by all standards, tried to maintain this business that he started with a little capital from his previous farming business. He sells a variety of garments and looks after farms.

His main setback is having little stock; therefore, acquiring this loan will help him buy more varied clothes to attract more customers. This will enable him to get more sales revenue and pay his family bills as he looks at educating his children and expanding his business. He belongs to Bukere Twimukye group, whose members hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

loans.use: to purchase more bales of clothes

loans.name: Sitina

texts.en: Sitina R. is a 48-year-old mother of four children; one is 12 years old and three are older than 18. Sitina is a businesswoman who owns a food kiosk in Shanzu, Mombasa and also owns rental houses in Mombasa. She has been in the rental business for 29 years and her business is doing well. This marks her second loan from KADET LTD, which she plans to use to add into her savings, to buy materials for building and to purchase more foodstuffs for her food kiosk. She intends to build another rental house. Sitina's dream is to own many rental houses in Mombasa.

loans.use: to add into her savings, to buy materials for building and to purchase more foodstuffs for her food kiosk

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca A. is from the village of Mimbunga, Gingoog City. She is 41 years old, married and has 6 school-aged children. Rebecca owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Rebecca has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Rebecca joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rebecca has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rebecca is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Rebecca from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital

loans.name: Lerita

texts.en:
Lerita A. is from the village of Nabannagan, Lasam, Cagayan. She is 52 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. Lerita owns and operates a business manufacturing hollow blocks. Lerita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month from it.

Lerita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lerita is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to open a new business: a store. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Lerita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to open a new business: a store

loans.name: God's Grace Kikaaya "a"-Kampala Group

texts.en: With the help of affirmative action, many Ugandan women have disproved the old rule that business is an activity only for men. N. Teopista, 38, who belongs to God’s grace Kikaaya "A"-Kampala, exemplifies these new women in today's Uganda. This happily married mother of five, who describes herself as honest, hard-working and pro-people, has been banking on her will power as a cardinal stock in trade in her second-hand clothes sales and brick-laying businesses in Kikaaya market-Kampala. She started this business with savings from her pig sales business, though she also dealt in poultry. In a week, her business generates 70,000 shillings. With this loan she wants to buy more bales of second-hand clothing for resale and also improve her brick-laying business.

loans.use: To purchase bales of clothes for resale and to also improve her brick-laying business

loans.name: Davenews

texts.en: Davenews W. is a 36-year-old married father of three children. He has been in the motorbike and bicycle transport business for two years. Davenews is borrowing his first loan from KADET LTD and intends to purchase a secondhand motorcycle for transportation. He has been serving the residents of Mamba in Nyali and has been able to provide for his family with his income. Davenews hopes to save some money and open a business for his wife to be able to support his family better.

loans.use: to purchase a secondhand motorcycle

loans.name: Cris

texts.en:
Cris P. is from the village of Lapinig, Balingoan, Misamis Oriental. He is 25 years old and single. Cris owns and operates a business providing motorcycle or habal-habal services to local community members. Cris has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Cris joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cris is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Cris from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

Revelita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Revelita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Revelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Revelita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Revelita from ASKI. loans.name: Tonimar's Group

texts.en:
Tonimar C. is from the village of Fugo Echague. She is 40 years old. Tonimar is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Tonimar C. group.

Tonimar is married and has 3 school-aged children. She owns and operates a weaving business, selling specialty hand-woven products to tourists and local community members. Tonimar has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Tonimar joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tonimar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase raw materials to make woven products. Tonimar is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make woven products. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Tonimar from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic A. is from the village of Malinao, Gingoog City. She is 37 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Marivic owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Marivic has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Marivic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marivic is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Marivic from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah M. is a 48-year-old poultry farmer and a saloon proprietor in Shanzu Mombasa. Her husband supports her income and they are blessed with three children. She has been in these businesses for the last eighteen years and her income is great. 

With her second loan from KADET LTD, she would like to buy day-old chicks for her farm, rear them to maturity and sell them . She hopes to use the anticipated profit to educate her children. Annah would like to become a big farmer in the future.

loans.use: to buy day-old chicks for her farm

loans.name: Nazziba Central Womens Group-Kampala

texts.en:
Jolly and civil, 56-year-old N. Jane belongs to the Nazziba Central group-Kampala. She is proud of her joyous demeanor given that it has played right into her favour as she operates her pub business. Clients have been coming in droves, knowing well that she connects with them in cracking jokes that exhilarate them. People in Uganda have different ways of attracting customers and to Jane this is the best way she knows.

After 10 years selling alcohol and soft drinks, which are in such high favor with Ugandans, she has developed solid business experience that she says will only help in making her business stronger. This married mother of 4 says she makes weekly profits to the tune of 150,000 UGX. Prior to this, she worked as a parking lot attendant. With this loan, she wants to buy more crates of both hard and soft drinks for her pub.

loans.use: to purchase more crates of hard and soft drinks

loans.name: Phenh

texts.en: Phenh P., 46, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. P. is a farmer and she also produces traditional baskets for an income of US $4 per day.  P. is requesting a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to school. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the children to commute to school

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn L. is from the village of Malinao, Gingoog City. She is 30 years old, separated from her spouse and has 3 school-aged children. Marilyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Marilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Marilyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Learnie's Group

texts.en:
Learnie B. is from the village of Sta. Isabel Norte. She is 32 years old. Learnie is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Learnie B..

Learnie is married and has 3 school-aged children. She owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Learnie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Learnie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Learnie is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Learnie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Rang

texts.en:
Rang N., 28, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. N. sells fish for an income of USD 8 per day. her husband is a fisherman, earning an income of USD 3.50 per day. Currently, N. uses her bicycle to transport fish to sell.  

N. is requesting a loan of USD 900 to purchase a motorbike to transport fish to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike to transport fish to sell

loans.name: Kalandar

texts.ru: Ашуров Каландар житель города Турсунзаде. Возраст, 54 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Сын на заработках в России. Сам Каландар имеет среднее образование. Более 30 лет занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота, чтобы увеличить количество скот.
texts.en:
Kalandar A. lives in Tursun-zoda. He is 54 years old, married, and has three children. His son works in Russia. Kalandar has a high school education. For more than thirty years, he has been working in animal husbandry. He raises cattle at his home. He is taking out a loan to buy cattle to increase his herd.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Sosela

texts.en:
Sosela M. is from the village of Minsapinit, Gingoog City. She is 52 years old. Sosela is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Sosela owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies like sweetened rice cake and steamed cake in the local community. Sosela has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Sosela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sosela is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Sosela from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his stock

loans.name: Ruth Jesang

texts.en:
Ruth Jesang K. is a 40-year-old lady married to Mathew K.. They have seven children aged 22 years, 18 years, 15 years, 12 years,10 years, eight years and four years respectively. They live in Kapseret 10 km from Eldoret town. Ruth has a dairy farm  and also sells clothes, where she earns her income. She has been in this business for the past 10 years with an income of Kshs. 8,000 per month.

Ruth was introduced to KADET LTD by a Credit Officer and she is applying for her first loan of Kshs 35,000 with KADET LTD with which she plans to purchase second-hand clothes for resale. 

She hopes to operate large-scale boutique in future.

loans.use: To purchase second-hand clothes for resale

loans.name: Veoun

texts.en:
Veoun S., 59, is married and resides with her husband and one child in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. S. sells groceries for an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband is a carpenter, earning an income of USD 5 per day.  

S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Hay

texts.en:
Hay N., 30, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. N. is a farmer and she also grows vegetables for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is an electrician, earning an income of USD 5 per day. 

 N. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a water pump to water her vegetables. In the future, she would like to use aN. additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: a water pump to water the vegetables

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma L. is from the village of San Luis, Gingoog City. She is 45 years old. Gemma is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Gemma owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gemma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Gemma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

location.town: San Luis, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Duong's Group

texts.en:
Duong T. T. D. is a 26 year old farmer and glove maker.  She has one young child.  Duong has been in business for four year, since she accessed our credit program in 2006.  Based on the small loan size, she can earn 2000,000 VND per month.  Currently, Duong is in need of a loan of 5,450,000 VND to buy material to make thousands of gloves.

Chien T. N. is 28 years old.  She has a work shop that produces wood products.  In business for four years, she wants a loan of 4,142,000 VND to buy more wood.
 
Hieu T.  D.  is 53 years old.  She grows rice and raises poultry.  Hieu seeks to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy food and fertilizer.

Hai T. H., 47, runs a small grocery shop.  She needs to borrow 5,886,000 VND to buy more products to meet the demand of customers.

loans.use: Buy business supplies.

loans.name: Hermosa

texts.en:
Hermosa H. is a 62-year-old loving mother of four children whose ages range from 21 to 31 years old, and a member of KIVA field partner in the Philippines, ASHI. She is requesting a greater loan amount to overcome the financial deficit which hinders the growth of her business and its profit, as well as her dream of improving her family's lifestyle. 

Hermosa’s supportive husband, Domingo H., is a fisherman. The income he gets out of his fishing is small and sporadic, therefore, Hermosa has to do her part of earning to achieve her simple dream in life: to provide a better living for her children, who currently live in poverty. Loan access is her only hope of reaching her goal.

A proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2002, Hermosa has demonstrated regular attendance at weekly meetings and steady repayments on previous loans.

Hermosa’s dreams are to expand her fishing business and eventually invest in more fishing equipment so that someday she will provide employment to others.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, she aspires to grow her business and generate steady income to support her family’s long term financial security.

loans.use: To support and maintain her fishing business

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
N. Emmanuel, aged 30 years, with a family of two children, has been operating a retail shop in Ikoba trading centre, Kyenjojo  selling general merchandise for over three years. Here he trades in a variety of household items like sugar, soap, salt, cooking oil, and much more merchandise, earning him a profit of 1,560,000 Ugandan shillings. His main drawback is that he has a limited stock of products in his shop that cannot satisfy the customers' demand. 

Therefore he is looking forward to increasing his stock when he gets this loan and also expanding into a wholesale shop. This will help him earn more revenue and sustain his daily needs as he envisions improving his family’s standard of living and further starting up a produce-selling business in the area.

loans.use: purchase more stock for the business

loans.name: Naluvule Rural Women's Association-Kampala Group

texts.en:
35-year-old N. Dorothy, who belongs to Naluvule rural women’s group, Kampala, radiates warmth, a sparky sense of humor, and above all good relationship skills. These have been virtues that have for the last decade championed her cause in her charcoal sales business in Naluvule-Kampala. 

With no prior business experience, this happily married mother of 10 knew the aforementioned attributes would come in handy, especially in helping her obtain a footing. In a week, she makes shillings 50,000 and with this loan she wants to purchase more bags of charcoal for resale.

loans.use: The purchase of more bags of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Henry Kiptoo

texts.en:
Henry Kiptoo A. is a businessman, 36 years old, who produces dairy products and sells them to his customers at a profit. He is married to Esther A., and they have three children aged seven years, four years and 11 years respectively. He runs his business in Kapseret,10 km from Eldoret town and has been in this business for about five years.

Henry was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer and he has no history with any other MFI.He is applying for his first loan of Kshs 30,000 with KADET LTD with which he plans to buy more milk for re-sale.


He hopes to operate a large-scale dairy farm, whereby he will be able to supply milk to the entire village.

loans.use: To buy more milk for re-sale

loans.name: Gloria's Group

texts.en:
Gloria T. is from the village of Malamag East. She is 59 years old. Gloria is the group leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Gloria T.'.

Gloria is widowed and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Gloria owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables in the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Gloria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nuru

texts.ru:
Nuru I. 50 let. On imeyet 3 detey, dochka 21 qod uchitsya v universitete, dochka 18 let v etom qodu postupila v universitet i sin 16 let uchitsya v shkole i zanimayetsya sportom. Nuru yavlyayetsya IDP personom ,on pereselenec iz Kalbadjar, seychas projivayet v Absheron region.

Nuru uje 15 let kak rabotayet v etom biznesse peremesheniye passajirov.
Etomu biznessu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo dedushki kotoriy toje bil voditelem avtobusa. Seychas Nuru nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit zapchasti dlya toqo chto pochinit mashinu.
texts.en:
Nuru I. is fifty years old. He has three children. His 21-year-old daughter studies at the university. His eighteen-year-old daughter is entering the university this year, and his sixteen-year-old son goes to school and plays sports. Nuru is an IDP (internally displaced person). He is a refugee from Kalbadjar and now lives in the Absheron region. For the last fifteen years, Nuru has been working transporting passengers. He started this business with his grandfather who was also a bus driver. Now, Nuru needs 2000 AZN to buy parts to repair his vehicle.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying car parts

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn L., 47, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. L. is a housewife while her husband is a farmer, earning an income of USD 7 per day.  L. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase fertilizer to improver her family farm. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy fertilizer to improve the family farm

loans.name: 02.05.17 Group

texts.en:
Luan L. T. (15) is a 50-year-old woman living in the town of Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  luan is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 17 (02.05.17).


Luan is married and has 3 adult children.  To make a living, Luan operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising cattL. for saL..  Luan has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 1,500,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2002, Luan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Luan has successfully repaid a previous loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  This will be the 20th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Luan plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  L. T. Thoan (39) is a 60-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 8.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  N. T. Bon (30) is a 51-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


luan L. T. (15) là 50 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  luan là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 17 (02.05.17).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  luan thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 30 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, luan kiếm được khoảng 1.500.000 VND.  Vào 2002, luan đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  luan đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 20th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. thoan (39) là 60 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 8.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  N. T. bon (30) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Sosik

texts.en:
Sosik S. lives in Vardavank village, Kapan area with his wife. His three children are already married and live separately from their parents. Sosik has a secondary school education and now he works in a private household as a hired worker. At the same time he has his own farm, where he raises sheep, cows, goats and pigs. Sosik's wife helps him a lot in this laborious work, and thanks to their farming, Sosik and his wife support their family and their farm. 

Sosik is asking for a 600,000 AMD loan to buy 12 ewes for his farm. Expanding his herd of livestock will allow him to develop his farm and to earn more profit.

loans.use: To buy 12 ewes for his farm

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en:
Kalsoom lives in an industrial city of Pakistan called Gujranwala. She is a 32-year-old housewife as well as a businesswoman who supports her family by doing sewing. She collects orders from her neighborhood clients and supplies the finished goods on time to earn an income. Her business is doing well and she earns a reasonable income from it every month.
 
She is the mother of a son and two daughters. Her eldest, a son, is studying in 3rd standard and her daughters are in 2nd and kindergarten respectively. 

Her husband is a rickshaw driver by trade. He drives a rickshaw to support the family. He has been in this line of work for the past 5 years.  His rickshaw is his only source of income because he doesn’t have any other work experience. But now his rickshaw is creating problems for him because its engine is not working well and requires maintenance.  

Therefore, Kalsoom has applied for a loan from Asasah. With the loan amount he will repair his rickshaw and put it back in working condition. Kalsoom is confident that the completely overhauled rickshaw will help her husband work efficiently.

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is on her 3rd loan.  In previous years she has maintained a good credit record and never missed any meeting.

Note: In the picture, the lady who is holding a book (called an Asasah Passbook) in her hand is Kalsoom.

loans.use: To repair a rickshaw

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en:
Narantsetseg G. is 32 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Ulaanabaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian housing tent in a rented yard. Her older daughter, Enhtuya, attends secondary school and her younger daughter is in kindergarten. Her husband operates a taxi service in the local community to supplement the family income. 

Narantsetseg manages a vegetable trading business in the market. She has been engaged this business since 2007 in the local market in Ulaanbaatar. She has found success and has built up a stable business operation. For the future, she plans to purchase land with a fence near her children's school and the market where she sells her products. She is a very modest and hard-working woman and is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase fresh vegetables to sell for profit.

loans.use: To purchase fresh vegetables

loans.name: Huong

texts.en: Huong T. N. is 27 years old with one daughter.  She runs a busy shop that provides photocopy services for local companies.  Running this business since 2004, loans have helped her do more business.  Currently, Huong wants a loan of 8,502,000 VND to buy another photocopy machine to meet the increase in customer orders.

loans.use: Buy another photocopy machine.

loans.name: Gantumur

texts.en:
Gantumur N. is 44 years old and lives with his wife and daughters in Huvsgul province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His older daughter, Setgelmaa, is a student while his younger daughter, Bolormaa, attends a local secondary school.  

Gantumur, with the help of his wife, operates a car repair business in a rented workplace in his town. He began his business in 1998 and since then, they have built up a successful business operation. Over many years of operation, he has gained a lot of experience. His earnings have enabled him to pay his daughter's tuition fees and also provide for his family. 

For the future, he hopes to have his own workplace. Gantumur is a very hard-working and modest man and is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan in order to purchase some repair parts and tools for his business.

loans.use: To purchase some repair parts and tools

loans.name: 05.01.19 Group

texts.en:
Nien N. T. (48) is a 62-year-old woman living in the town of Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  Nien is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 19 (05.01.19).


Nien is married and has 2 adult children.  To make a living, Nien operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising cattL. for saL..  Nien has been engaged in this business for over 40 years and earns approximately 1,500,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2010, Nien joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Nien is requesting for the first time a loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Womenin the amount of 4,248,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  The will be the 12th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Nien plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  L. T. Tam (49) is a 47-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock24

2.  T. T. Sen (50) is a 34-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4,428.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

loans.name: Handdorj

texts.en:
Handdorj S. is 69 years old and lives with his wife in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his wife live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent in a 'ger' district of Ulaanbaatar. His wife is retired. 

Handdorj operates a shoe repair business. He has been repairing a variety of boots in his workshop near the bus station in Ulaanbaatar, since 2000. He also makes felt slippers for sale. His daily average income is between 20,000-30,000 MNT.

 Handdorj hopes to grow his business. He is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan in order to buy more repair materials and supplies for his business.

loans.use: To buy more repair materials and supplies

loans.name: Khanh

texts.en: Khanh T. N. is 52 years old with one child who attends a vocational school.  She sells fresh vegetables and fruit.  Her business has grown over the past four years and her family's living conditions are directly linked to her business' success.  Khanh has always been a good re-payer.  Currently, she wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to invest in her shop.

loans.use: Invest in her shop

loans.name: Myagmardorj

texts.en:
Myagmardorj Y. is 48 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His older daughter is going to marry soon. His middle child, a son, 22, is a student while his younger daughter, 12, attends a local secondary school. His wife works as a servant in a City Accomplishment Agency. 

Myagmardorj operates a coal selling business in his town. He started his business in 1999 and has built up a stable operation. He is a very modest and hardworking person and is requesting a 1,050,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood and coal from neighboring sub-provinces for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and coal
